member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Analysis.Monitoring.PeakDetector
member.summary: Calculates the location, amplitude, and second derivatives of peaks or valleys in the input array.
member.remarks:
The input data might either be a single array or consecutive blocks of data. Consecutive blocks of data are useful for large data arrays or for real-time processing.
This method is based on an algorithm that fits a quadratic polynomial to sequential groups of data points. The number of data points used in the fit is specified by .
For , the quadratic fit is tested against the level. Peaks with heights lower than the level or valleys with troughs higher than the level are ignored. Peaks/valleys are detected only after approximately /2 data points have been processed beyond peaks/valleys locations. This delay has implications only for real-time processing.
member.example:
The following example filters a Gaussian noise signal and calculates several measurements associated with the peaks and valleys of the filtered signal.
Dim signalIn(), noiseWaveform() As Double Dim amplitudes() As Double = Nothing, locations() As Double = Nothing, secondDerivatives() As Double = Nothing Dim initialThreshold As Double Dim initialWidth As Integer Dim endOfData As Boolean Dim peakDetector As New PeakDetector Dim gaussianNoise As New GaussianNoiseSignal(1.0, 1) Dim ellipticFilter As New EllipticLowpassFilter(2, 1.0, 0.125, 1.0, 60.0)
' Generate noise signal and filter the data noiseWaveform = gaussianNoise.Generate(100.0, 100) signalIn = ellipticFilter.FilterData(noiseWaveform)
' Set initial state of peakDetector initialThreshold = 0.0 initialWidth = 3 peakDetector.Reset(initialThreshold, initialWidth, PeakPolarity.Peaks)
endOfData = True
' Find location of amplitude, locations and second derivates of peaks in signalIn array peakDetector.Detect(signalIn, endOfData, amplitudes, locations, secondDerivatives)
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Analysis .NET Library Concepts
Professional Edition Peak Detector (Enterprise and Professional editions)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Analysis.Monitoring.PeakDetector.#ctor(System.Double,System.Int32,NationalInstruments.Analysis.Monitoring.PeakPolarity)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified parameters.
member.param: The threshold value that rejects peaks and valleys that are too small.
The number of consecutive data points to be used in the quadratic least-squares fit. This value must be greater than or equal to 3.
Whether the method looks for peaks (positive-going bumps) or valleys (negative-going bumps) in the input signal.
member.exception: is less than three.
Specified is invalid.
The analysis library cannot be found.
A required operation in the analysis library cannot be found.
member.remarks:
For peaks, the method ignores any peak found with a fitted amplitude that is less than . The method ignores valleys if the fitted trough is greater than . This input is used to eliminate the effect of noise in the input data.
is coerced to a value greater than or equal to 3. The value should be no more than about 1/2 of the half-width of the peaks/valleys and can be much smaller (but 2) for noise-free data. Large widths can reduce the apparent amplitude of peaks and shift the apparent location. For noisy data, this modification is unimportant since the noise obscures the actual peak. Ideally, should be as as small as possible but must be balanced against the possibility of false peak detection due to noise.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.ArbitrarySignal.Generate(System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Generates an array containing an arbitrary wave.
member.param: The sampling rate, in hertz.
The desired number of samples.
member.returns: The array containing the arbitrary waveform.

exception.para: is less than or equal to zero.
is less than or equal to zero.

member.exception: The analysis library cannot be found.
A required operation in the analysis library cannot be found.
member.remarks:
If the sequence Y represents the output arbitrary signal, the method generates the pattern according to the following formula:
yi = a[arb(phasei)]
where
i = 0, 1,..., n1,
a represents the amplitude,
n represents the ,
arb(phasei) = WT[(phasei modulo 360)(m/360)], and
m represents the size of the wave table.
,
phase0 = the value of the property when is called,
fsignal represents the frequency of the triangle signal, and
fsampling is the sampling rate.
If interpolation = 0 (no interpolation), then WT(x) = Wave Table[int(x)].
If interpolation = 1 (linear interpolation), then WT(x) is equal to the linearly interpolated value of the wave table[int(x)] and wave table[(int(x) + 1) modulo m].
The method updates the value of the property to the phase of the point after the last one returned. This means that can be called successively to generate a continuous triangle wave points at a time.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.BasicFunctionGenerator
member.summary: Generates sine, square, sawtooth, and triangle waveforms.
member.remarks:
This class provides static and instance methods that you can use to generate waveform arrays. Use the static methods to fill arrays with signal patterns, specified using .
To generate continuous waveforms, create an instance of this class and then use the method to start the waveform generation. The method updates the value of the property to the phase of the point after the last one returned. This means that can be called successively to generate a continuous wave points at a time.

member.remarks:
The method generates the Gaussian-distributed pseudorandom sequence using a modified version of the Very-Long-Cycle random number generator algorithm based upon the Central Limit Theorem. The pseudorandom number generator implements a triple-seeded linear congruential algorithm. Given that the probability density function, f(x), of the Gaussian-distributed Gaussian Noise Pattern is
where s represents the absolute value of the specified standard deviation,
and that you can compute the expected values, E{}, using the formula
then the expected mean value, , and the expected standard deviation value, , of the pseudorandom sequence are
The pseudorandom sequence produces approximately 290 samples before the pattern repeats itself.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.HaltonSequence
member.summary: Generates a quasi-random Halton sequence, which is a low-discrepancy number sequence.
member.remarks:
The quasi-random sequence is a sequence with low discrepancy that uniformly distributes the interval [0,1].
You can use this class alone to generate a quasi-random sequence, or you can add it to the
collection of a class to generate it as part of a composite signal.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.PeriodicNoiseSignal
member.summary: Generates an array containing periodic pseudorandom noise.

remarks.para: You can use this class to compute the frequency response of a linear system in one time record instead of averaging the frequency response over several time records, as you must for nonperiodic random noise sources.

You do not need to window periodic random noise before performing spectral analysis because periodic random noise is self-windowing and therefore has no spectral leakage. This is because periodic random noise contains only integral-cycle sinusoids.

You can use this class alone to generate a periodic noise signal, or you can add it to the
collection of a class to generate it as part of a composite signal.

remarks.para: This method generates an array containin a Poisson-distributed pseudorandom pattern of values that are the number of discrete eventes that occur in the interval specified by of a unit rate Poisson process. The following equation defines the probability density function:
where is the mean.
The following equations define the mean value, , and the standard deviation value, , of the pseudorandom sequence:

Poisson noise is the result of the Poisson process. You can use the Poisson process to describe the probability of a certain number of events happening in a given period of time. For example, you can use the Poisson process to describe the nuclear decay of atoms or the number of messages a transmitting station receives.

member.remarks:
If the sequence Y represents the sawtooth wave, the method generates the pattern according to the following formula:
yi = a * sawtooth(phasei)
where
i = 0, 1,..., n1,
a represents the amplitude,
n represents ,
p = phasei modulo 360.0,
,
phase0 = the value of the property when is called,
fsignal represents the frequency of the triangle signal, and
fsampling is the sampling rate.
The method updates the value of the property to the phase of the point after the last one returned. This means that can be called successively to generate a continuous sawtooth wave points at a time.

member.summary: Generates a sine signal.
member.remarks: You can use this class alone to generate a sine signal or you can add it to the collection of a class to generate it as part of a composite signal.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.SineSignal.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a .
member.exception: The analysis library cannot be found.
A required operation in the analysis library cannot be found.
member.remarks: For information on how the signal is generated, refer to the method.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Analysis.SignalGeneration.SineSignal.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a with the specified frequency.
member.param: The frequency of the resulting sine wave signal, in hertz.
member.exception: is less than or equal to zero.
The analysis library cannot be found.
A required operation in the analysis library cannot be found.
member.remarks:
If the sequence Y represents the sine wave, the method generates the pattern according to the following formula:
yi = a * sin(phasei)
where
i = 0, 1,..., n1,
a represents the amplitude,
n represents the number of samples,
phasei = initial phase + 360.0fi,
f represents the in normalized units of cycles/sample, and
initial phase represents the phase in if the reset phase is , or
initial phase represents the phase out from the previous execution of this instance if the reset phase is .
The method is reentrant, so you can use it to simulate a continuous acquisition from a sine wave function generator. If the input control reset phase is , subsequent calls to a specific instance of the method produce the output sine wave array containing the next samples of a sine wave.
Because the method is a reentrant method, when the reset phase is set to , the method uses the phase out value as its new phase in the next time the method executes.

member.param: The frequency of the resulting sine wave signal, in hertz.
The amplitude of the resulting sine wave signal.
The initial phase of the resulting sine wave signal, in degrees.
member.exception: is less than or equal to zero.
The analysis library cannot be found.

member.remarks:
If the sequence Y represents the sine wave, the method generates the pattern according to the following formula:
yi = a * sin(i)
where
i = 0, 1,..., n1,
a represents ,
n represents the number of samples,
i = initial + 360.0fi,
f represents the in normalized units of cycles/sample, and
initial represents the in if the reset is , or
initial represents the out from the previous execution of this instance if the reset is .
The method is reentrant, so you can use it to simulate a continuous acquisition from a sine wave function generator. If the input control reset phase is , subsequent calls to a specific instance of the method produce the output sine wave array containing the next samples of a sine wave.
Because the method is a reentrant method, when the reset is set to , the method uses the out value as its new in the next time the method executes.

The method updates the value of the property to the phase of the point after the last one returned. This means that can be called successively to generate a continuous sine wave points at a time.
